coredata.dc:title: Overall water splitting on surface-polarized Sn3O4 through weakening the trap of Sn(II) to holes
coredata.dc:creator: Chen, Lu
Yue, Shuai
Wang, Jing
Chen, Wanhu
Zhang, Yajun
Xie, Mingzheng
Han, Weihua
coredata.dc:description: As an ideal candidate for photocatalytic overall water splitting, Sn3O4 only be active with the help of hole sacrificial agent. In this work, we reveal the corresponding mechanism and provide a feasible strategy based on surface polarization. The results show that the Sn(II) in Sn3O4 would trap the holes and then be oxidized during water splitting, leading to photocorrosion and weak oxygen evolution activity. The phosphoric acid modification could enhance the activity of Sn3O4 for oxygen evolution, and overall water splitting is achieved accordingly. The hydrogen and oxygen evolution rates can reach up to 9.6 and 4.5 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively. It is mainly due to the modified phosphate groups could make Sn3O4 carry more negative charges by ionization in water. The generated surface electric field could weaken the trapping effect, thus the holes can arrive at the surface effectively, along with improved stability and charge carrier separation.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Sn3O4
Overall water splitting
Preferred oxidation of Sn(II)
Trapping effect
Surface polarization

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: The morphology and crystal structure. (a)–(d) are SEM and TEM images of 2P-APT@Sn3O4 at different magnifications. (e) is EDX spectrum and (f)–(i) are EDS elemental maps. (j) and (k) are XRD patterns and FT-IR spectra, respectively.

The photocatalytic stability and structural change. (a) is I-t curves and (b) is Raman spectra. (c) and (d) are XPS spectra of Sn 3d and O1s. (e) is UV-Vis absorption spectra and (f) is the Tauc-plots before and after photocatalysis.

Surface and photogenerated charge properties. (a) is Zeta potential of samples at different pH. (b) is the absorption efficiency to rhodamine B at pH = 7. (c) is the potential distribution in 2P-APT@Sn3O4 simulated by COMSOL. (d) and (e) are the PL and TR-PL spectra of samples. (f) is the charge separation efficiency. (g) and (h) are Bode phase plots and Mott-Schottky curves, respectively. (i) is the hole diffusion length at 400 nm wavelength.

The photocatalytic activity for splitting water. (a) is overall water splitting activities of different samples. (b) and (c) are the amounts of generated gas with reaction time and in 5 successive cycles of 2P-APT@Sn3O4, respectively. (d) is IPCE spectra at 0.3 V.

Mechanism for enhanced photocatalytic activity. (a) is schematic of charge separation and transfer of Sn3O4 under the influence of surface polarization. (b) is the designed installation for rhodamine B degradation. (c) and (d) are the influence of applied bias on rhodamine B degradation rate. (e) is the PL spectra of 7-hydroxycoumarin formed by different samples in 10 min.

The influence of strengthened surface polarization based on multiple acid modifications. (a), (b) and (c) are the SEM image, EDX spectra and XPS survey spectrum of 1B/2P-APT@Sn3O4, respectively. (d) is Zeta potential of samples at pH = 7 and (e) is the potential distribution in 1B/2P-APT@Sn3O4 simulated by COMSOL. (f), (g) and (h) are the PL spectra, I-t curves and Mott-Schottky curves, respectively.
Preparation process of amorphous TiO2 and phosphoric acid decorated Sn3O4.

head.ce:title: Overall water splitting on surface-polarized Sn3O4 through weakening the trap of Sn(II) to holes

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: L. Chen and S. Yue contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: As an ideal candidate for photocatalytic overall water splitting, Sn3O4 only be active with the help of hole sacrificial agent. In this work, we reveal the corresponding mechanism and provide a feasible strategy based on surface polarization. The results show that the Sn(II) in Sn3O4 would trap the holes and then be oxidized during water splitting, leading to photocorrosion and weak oxygen evolution activity. The phosphoric acid modification could enhance the activity of Sn3O4 for oxygen evolution, and overall water splitting is achieved accordingly. The hydrogen and oxygen evolution rates can reach up to 9.6 and 4.5 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively. It is mainly due to the modified phosphate groups could make Sn3O4 carry more negative charges by ionization in water. The generated surface electric field could weaken the trapping effect, thus the holes can arrive at the surface effectively, along with improved stability and charge carrier separation.

Photocatalytic overall water-splitting is realized on surface-polarized Sn3O4 through inducing the trapped holes to transport to surface.
ga1

ce:section.ce:para: Semiconductor photocatalysis is a promising way to utilize solar energy because it could split water into hydrogen and oxygen under solar light [1–5]. An ideal photocatalyst is expected to have superior light absorption, ability to overall water splitting and good stability. For the former two advantages, the photocatalyst is required to possess appropriate band structure. In particular, the band gap should be narrow so that it can absorb enough solar light, and its conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) positions could meet the energy requirements for hydrogen and oxygen evolution. Only a few candidates could simultaneously fulfill the two requirements. Sn3O4 is a promising candidate due to its proper band gap of about 2.75 eV [6,7], which guarantee considerable solar light (wavelength shorter than 450 nm) could be utilized. It also has an appropriate energy level position, whose CB level is 0.7 eV higher than the proton reduction potential [8,9], and its VB level locates at 2 V (vs. SHE, pH = 0) which is energetic enough for oxygen evolution, theoretically [10]. However, experimental results show that Sn3O4 is only active in the presence of hole sacrificial agent in water splitting [11,12].

It is well known that Sn3O4 is a kind of mixed-valence oxide, containing Sn(II) and Sn(IV). Previous investigation shows that the material involving Sn(II) is impotent to generate oxygen over water splitting [13]. Li et al. believed that the doped Sn(II) in polymeric carbon nitride would serve as hole-traps [14]. Kudo et al. found that the ion-exchanged Sn(II) in K4Nb6O17 would be irreversibly oxidized by the photogenerated holes [15], and similar phenomenon was also observed in our previous work [10]. It implies that there must be some kind of interaction between Sn(II) and holes in Sn3O4, which leads to the weak activity for oxygen evolution and other adverse effects, such as photocorrosion. Obviously, it is important to reveal the interaction mechanism for the realization of overall water splitting on Sn3O4. However, there are rare works carried out on this point to the best of our knowledge.

As a kind of species carrying positive charge, the behavior of photogenerated holes are easily affected by electric field [16,17]. A negatively charged surface will attract photogenerated holes to the surface effectively, as verified in our previous works [18,19]. Such an attraction will help the photogenerated holes escape from surface traps. Therefore, a negatively charged surface may be conducive to weaken the possibly existed trapping effect of Sn(II) in Sn3O4, by which overall water splitting is expected to be realized. Generally, photocatalyst surface could carry negative charges in alkaline solution [20,21]. However, it is slight, thus the generated electric field is too weak to make holes free of trapping by surface traps. Moreover, the alkaline environment is harmful to the performance stability of photocatalysts.

Surface modification with functional molecules is a commonly used strategy to change the surface charge state of photocatalysts [22–24]. Our previous works indicated that some inorganic acid with poly-hydroxyl features, such as phosphoric acid, can be used to modify photocatalyst surface by substituting the adsorbed hydroxyl groups [25]. The modified functional molecules could be ionized in water, thus the photocatalyst surface carries more negative charges in neutral environment. The zeta potential of BiVO4 could be increased from − 20 mV to − 75 mV in neutral water by phosphoric acid modification [18], and it is further increased to ~ − 100 mV after being co-modified with boric acid [19]. Naturally, such a surface polarization is expected to provide a stable and strong surface negative electric field on Sn3O4, and then the holes would prefer to transport to the surface, rather than react with Sn(II). In addition, coating of passivation layer, such as amorphous TiO2, is an effective way to inhibit the photocorrosion [26,27]. And it usually rare hinder the charge carrier transport and realization of redox reaction due to the thin thickness of several nanometers.

Hence, the preferred interaction between holes and Sn(II) in Sn3O4 is studied in this work, and surface polarization based on inorganic acid modification is exploited to inhibit it. The results show that the generated holes during photocatalysis would be trapped by the Sn(II) in Sn3O4, leading to the preferred oxidation of Sn(II). It could be inhibited by means of surface passivation and polarization, thus Sn3O4 becomes stable and possesses the ability to overall water splitting. This work provides a reference for the research about mixed-valence photocatalyst and a feasible strategy to enhance its photocatalytic activity.
In this work, all analytical reagents were used as received without further purification.

Phosphoric acid modified Sn3O4 was prepared through a 4-step process shown in Scheme 1. First, Sn3O4 was synthesized by a hydrothermal method [10]. Typically, 3.5 g of SnCl2 .2H2O was dissolved into 60 mL of deionized (DI) water, and then the pH of the mixed solution was adjusted to 13 by using 0.1 M NaOH. After being stirred for 30 min and sonicated for 5 min, the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave with a capacity of 100 mL for hydrothermal reaction at 180 °C for 16 h (step 1). Then, Sn3O4 was obtained by washing the yellow product several times with DI water and ethanol (step 2). Afterwards, the obtained Sn3O4 was dispersed into 50 mM TiCl4 solutions and kept stirring for 30 min at 70 °C. After being washed with DI water, the treated Sn3O4 was further annealed at 300 °C for 1 h. Finally, the Sn3O4 was coated with an amorphous TiO2 layer and named as APT@Sn3O4 (step 3).

Phosphoric acid modification was realized through a wet chemical process (step 4). Typically, 0.1 g of APT@Sn3O4 powder was dispersed into 10 mL of phosphoric acid solution with a specific concentration. The mixture was kept stirring at 80 °C until it is dried up, then the phosphoric acid modified Sn3O4 was obtained and denoted as xP-APT@Sn3O4, in which x represents the concentration of phosphoric acid solution (μmol/L). In addition, the Sn3O4 multiple-modified with phosphoric acid and boric acid was prepared by using 2P-APT@Sn3O4 as raw material and glycerol as a “bridge” through a wet chemical process [19]. And it is named as 1B/2P-APT@Sn3O4, in which 1B indicates the concentration of boric acid solution is 1.0 mM. The characterizations of prepared samples are described in Electronic Supplementary information (ESI) in detail.

The photocatalytic activities were evaluated by means of a LabSolar 6A inline hydrogen evolution system equipped with a gas chromatograph (GC7900). The reactor contained 100 mL of DI water and 0.1 g of powder sample as photocatalyst. A 300 W Xenon lamp was used as the light source. Prior to water splitting, 0.5 wt% Pt was deposited on the sample as co-catalyst by a photodeposition method [28]. After being irradiated, the amounts of generated hydrogen and oxygen were detected every 1 h by the gas chromatograph.

SEM and TEM images were captured to observe the morphologies of as-prepared samples. From Figs. S1a–e and 1 a–c the 2P-APT@Sn3O4 sample possesses a flower-like sphere structure which is consisted of numberous nanosheets. It is the same to the pristine Sn3O4, indicating the TiCl4 treatment and the modification with proper amount of phosphoric acid rarely changed the unique structure. However, if the concentration of phosphoric acid solution is too high (2.5 μmol/L), the structure of Sn3O4 would be destroyed (Fig. S1f). In Fig. 1 d, there are 2 facet distances of 0.33 nm and 0.27 nm observed, which are ascribed to the (111) and (210) planes of Sn3O4, respectively [29,30]. It is noted that the sample is covered with an amorphous layer with a thickness of ~ 2 nm. According to our previous work, it is the amorphous TiO2 resulted from TiCl4 treatment [31]. The EDX spectra and elemental maps shown in Figs. 1 e–i and S2 indicate the 2P-APT@Sn3O4 sample is composed of Sn, O, Ti, and P elements, and the distributions of coated amorphous TiO2 layer and modified phosphoric acid molecules are uniform.

The XRD patterns in Fig. 1 j show that the prepared Sn3O4 possesses the characteristics of triclinic phase Sn3O4 (JCPDS no. 16-0737) [32,33]. The diffraction peaks are almost unchanged after TiCl4 treatment and phosphoric acid modification, indicating these procedures have little influence on the crystal structure. Figs. S4 and 1 k show the FT-IR spectra of samples. From those, there are two absorption peaks at 485 and 630 cm−1 in Sn3O4, which belong to the vibration of Sn-O [8]. After TiCl4 treatment, there is a new peak at 545 cm−1 ascribed to the vibration of Ti-O-O appears. The phosphoric acid modification leads to the presence of another new peak at 984 cm−1 [34], implying there are phosphate groups loaded the Sn3O4 surface.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structural change of Sn3O4 during photocatalysis
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 2 a shows the I-t curves under the bias of 0.3 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The Sn3O4 sample exhibits an initial photocurrent of 4.3 μA cm−2, and it gradually decreases to 3.2 μA cm−2 in 2200 s, indicating a poor stability. The coating of amorphous TiO2 layer decreases the photocurrent to 3.6 μA cm−2, along with a very tiny decay. After being modified by phosphoric acid, the photocurrent was increased to 18 μA cm−2, about 4 times that of pristine Sn3O4. Moreover, the photocurrent density is kept very well during the measurement, implying that the stability of Sn3O4 is improved significantly by the coating and modification.

The structural changes during photocatalytic water splitting were studied by means of Raman spectra shown in Fig. 2 b. It is seen that there is a characteristic peak of SnO2 at ~ 650 cm−1 appears in Sn3O4 after photocatalysis [35,36], indicating the generation of SnO2 in Sn3O4. Conversely, such a change has not been observed in APT@Sn3O4 and 2P-APT@Sn3O4. In addition, the peaks of Sn3O4 were rarely influenced after TiO2 coating and phosphoric acid modification (Fig. S5), which is well in agreement with the results of the XRD patterns. The XPS spectra show that the 2P-APT@Sn3O4 sample is composed of Sn, O, T and P elements (Fig. S6). The mole ratio of Sn(IV) to Sn(II) in Sn3O4 is about 1:2 (Fig. 2 c), and it increases to 2:1 after photocatalytic water splitting. Since the XPS spectrum is a surface-sensitive technology, such a result indicates there are many Sn(II) in surface has transformed to Sn(IV). Obviously, after being coated by TiO2 layer and modified with phosphoric acid, the above transformation has been effectively inhibited. And the inhibition is further proved by the XPS spectra of O 1s shown in Fig. 2 d.

The change of crystal structure during photocatalysis is also reflected in UV-Vis spectra (Figs. 2 e, f and S7). Sn3O4 exhibits strong absorption to the light longer than 400 nm, indicating that it is visible light responded. And the converted Tauc-plot indicates its band-gap is 2.76 eV, which is consistent with the literatures [37,38]. After the water splitting reaction, the equivalent band-gap was widened to 2.84 eV. Since the band-gap of SnO2 (~ 3.6 eV) is wider than that of SnO (0.24 eV) [39–42], the band-gap widening implies the existence of SnO2. Differently, the light absorptions of APT@Sn3O4 and 2P-APT@Sn3O4 are almost the same as that of Sn3O4, and they are kept well during water splitting. It is indicated that the coated TiO2 layer and modified phosphate groups hardly influence the light absorption, but inhibit the change in band structure. Based on the above results, it is clear that the coating of amorphous layer and modification of phosphoric acid could effectively inhibit the Sn(II) oxidization in photocatalysis.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The role of surface polarization on charge carrier property
ce:section.ce:para: The influences of TiCl4 treatment and phosphoric acid modification on photogenerated charge carrier properties were studied, and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the isoelectric point of Sn3O4 and APT@Sn3O4 are 5.7 and 6.1, while that of 2P-APT@Sn3O4 is 3.8. The result indicates that the influence of amorphous TiO2 layer is rare but the phosphate acid modification makes the catalyst carry more negative charges. According to our previous work, it is mainly due to that the modified phosphate groups enhance the surface acidity [19]. In neutral water, the modified phosphate groups will be ionized, thus making Sn3O4 carry more negative charges on the surface. This charged surface was further proved by the results of rhodamine B adsorption (Fig. 3 b), which is a kind of cationic dye and would carry positive charges in neutral water [43,44]. The influence depth of surface-carried negative charges was simulated by means of COMSOL software. For 2P-APT@Sn3O4, the zeta potential is − 34.7 mV in neutral water, and the influence depth in Sn3O4 is ~ 9 nm (Fig. 3 c), while the thickness of Sn3O4 nanosheet is 20–50 nm.

Steady and time-resolved PL spectra were exploited to study the photogenerated charge properties. As shown in Fig. 3 d, after TiCl4 treatment, the PL signal of Sn3O4 is remarkably enhanced, suggesting a higher recombination rate of charge carriers. It is suggested that the Sn(II) in Sn3O4 still could act as recombination centers when the preferred oxidation is suppressed. On the contrary, the recombination is significantly suppressed after surface modification. The more the modified phosphate groups, the higher the charge carrier separation rate. However, it decreases once the modified phosphate groups are in excess (Fig. S8), which may because that excessive phosphate groups will hinder the charge transfer [19]. The time-resolved PL spectra shown in Fig. 3 e indicate that phosphoric acid modification would largely prolong the lifetime of photo-charge carrier, while TiCl4 treatment is impotent.

The photogenerated charge carrier properties were further investigated by means of PEC measurements. The photocurrent has been largely enhanced after being modified with phosphoric acid, meanwhile, the influence from TiO2 coating is negligible (Fig. S9). It is mainly due to the variation of charge separation efficiency in Sn3O4 (Fig. 3 f), rather than injection efficiency (Fig. S10), which is further proved by the EIS Nyquist spectra and corresponding fitting results (Fig. S11 and Table S1). According to the Bode phase plots shown in Fig. 3 g, the lifetimes of photogenerated charge carriers could be compared based on the equation of “τ = 1/2πfmax” [45,46], and the trend is the same to the results of time-resolved PL spectra. Fig. 3 h shows the Mott-Schottky curves, of which slope is inversely proportional to the charge carrier concentration. The calculated value of charge carrier concentration in 2P-APT@Sn3O4 is about 8.37 × 1017 cm−3, while those of Sn3O4 and APT@Sn3O4 are 4.31 × 1017 cm−3 and 3.95 × 1017 cm−3 (Table S2). Similarly, the hole diffusion lengths of samples at 400 nm wavelength were calculated (Fig. 3 i and Table S2). For 2P-APT@Sn3O4, the hole diffusion length is 135 nm, and those of APT@Sn3O4 and Sn3O4 are 9.73 nm and 7.26 nm, respectively.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photocatalytic activity for overall water splitting
ce:section.ce:para: Overall water splitting under the irradiation of a 300 W Xenon lamp was performed to evaluate the activities. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the Sn3O4 and APT@Sn3O4 samples show negligible activities for both hydrogen and oxygen evolution in 3 h. After being modified with phosphoric acid, the activity is remarkably improved which increased with the modifying amount. The 2P-APT@Sn3O4 delivers the highest activity among the prepared samples. The hydrogen generation rate is up to 9.6 μmol g−1 h−1, and that for oxygen evolution is 4.5 μmol g−1 h−1. The decreased performance of 2.5 P-APT@Sn3O4 is mainly attributed to the decreased photogenerated charge carrier separation rate. It is noted that the mole ratio of generated hydrogen and oxygen is kept at 2:1 approximately (Fig. 4 b). After 5 successive cycles, the activities of 2P-APT@Sn3O4 sample only slightly decrease, suggesting its good stability (Fig. 4 c). From the IPCE spectra shown in Fig. 4 d, the incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency of 2P-APT@Sn3O4 at 400 nm is 1.72%, while those for APT@Sn3O4 and Sn3O4 are 0.41% and 0.46%, respectively.

Based on above, it is clear that there is a preferred oxidation reaction between Sn(II) and photogenerated hole in Sn3O4 during photocatalysis. It leads to a weak oxidization ability which is responsible to the negligible activity for oxygen evolution, along with remarkable photocorrosion. TiCl4 treatment could coat Sn3O4 with a thin layer of amorphous TiO2, which suppresses photocorrosion. However, the photogenerated charge carrier property of Sn3O4 is rare improved because the Sn(II) still could trap the holes and act as recombination centers. Phosphoric acid modification makes the TiO2-protected Sn3O4 carry more negative charges on the surface through ionizing of phosphate groups in water. The generated surface electric field could make the trapped holes escape from surface traps and thus promote the charge carrier separation. As a result, the overall water splitting over modified Sn3O4 under visible light irradiation has been successfully achieved ( Fig. 5 a), while pristine Sn3O4 and corresponding composites are only active in the presence of hole sacrificial agent (Table S3).

The mentioned mechanism was further verified by the results of a series of designed experiments. Firstly, PEC degradation of rhodamine B dye on Sn3O4 and APT@Sn3O4 samples were carried out (Fig. 5 b). Well known, rhodamine B is a kind of cationic dye and easy to be adsorbed on the photocatalyst, and its degradation mainly depends on photogenerated holes [47]. During the reaction, a positive bias with a certain intensity was applied on the FTO to drive the photogenerated holes to transport to the film surface, and then oxidize rhodamine B molecules. From Fig. 5 c, d, both the Sn3O4 and APT@Sn3O4 samples exhibit negligible activity for rhodamine B degradation until the applied bias is enhanced to 0.55 V vs. Ag/AgCl. It is suggested that there must be hole traps in Sn3O4, and it could be weakened by external electric field. Secondly, the hole amount transport to the sample surface was compared by means of coumarin fluorescent probe, which is usually exploited to detect the hydroxyl radical. Since benzoquinone which is a superoxide radical sacrificial agent is added into the water, the generation of hydroxyl radical only relates to the photogenerated holes arriving at the surface. As shown in Fig. 5 e, the 2P-APT@Sn3O4 shows a rather high PL signal compared with Sn3O4 and APT@Sn3O4, indicating the surface polarization facilitates the hole transport in Sn3O4.

It is reasonable to conclude that the surface polarization is effective to promote hole transport to Sn3O4 surface. Our previous works indicated the activity enhancement depends on the intensity of surface-carried electric field. Hence, we further enhanced the degree of surface polarization by co-modification. As seen in Fig. 6a–c, the further modification of 2P-APT@Sn3O4 with boric acid by using glycerin as a “bridge” could make Sn3O4 carry more hydroxy groups without changing the morphology. The zeta potential is further enhanced to − 55.8 mV, and the influence depth of the electric field is widened to 15 nm (Fig. 6d, e). The PL and PEC results demonstrate that the enhanced surface polarization leads to improved charge carrier separation and concentration (Fig. 6f–h), which further proves its key role in enhancing the activity of Sn3O4.

In summary, we have verified that the Sn(II) in Sn3O4 would trap the holes during photocatalysis, leading to serious photocorrosion and poor activity for oxygen evolution. Surface passivation based on TiCl4 treatment coats Sn3O4 with an amorphous TiO2 layer with a thickness of 2 nm. It could suppress the photocorrosion of Sn3O4, but has no use in improving the charge carrier property and photocatalytic activity, which is attributed to that the Sn(II) acts as recombination centers. The trap is weakened by phosphoric acid modification, due to which Sn3O4 carries more negative charges on the surface in water. Such a surface polarization makes Sn3O4 under the influence of negative electric field, thus the trapped holes could transport to arrive at the surface and the charge carrier separation is promoted. As a result, overall water splitting over Sn3O4 was achieved, and hydrogen and oxygen evolution rates can reach 9.6 and 4.5 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively. This work provides a valuable reference to improve the activity of mixed-valence photocatalyst.

Lu Chen: Investigation, Data curation, Writing – original draft, Software. Shuai Yue: Investigation, Visualization, Validation. Jing Wang: Formal analysis, Data curation. Wanhu Chen: Data curation. Yajun Zhang: Resources. Mingzheng Xie: Supervision, Conceptualization, Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition. Weihua Han: Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition.
